author: @jaytaylor5967
text:
This movie disappointing a strange vampire that you never see his teeth. There's not much blood. The bloodiest part is during the part where the gross guide bites. The pigeons Head off, which was quite disturbing.
The best part to me was when he juiced the children and threw them down like Empty juice boxes.
The worst part was the ending. And also, when the vampire was humping the guy while he was sucking his blood, which was really stuvisually. The movie was okay. It had some well filmed parts. I was expecting something shocking, something adult. More adult than what we got something that your children could never see. Other than the fact, there's a male doing full frontal nudity, which I could have done without? I didn't need to see Vampire penis. So so compared to the North man, this movie is garbage.
And the ending is so absolutely stupid. Oh I just couldn't pull myself away from you because you're just so beautiful. I'm gonna kill myself. Because I'm so in love with you. I'm not gonna leave the Sun's coming up, but I'm too stupid to leave and then her she's so stupid. I'm gonna let him s*** m* dry because I am so stupid. It seemed like there was 20 minutes missing from the movie. At the end, there was no build up to the ending. There was no climax. There was no payoff. No satisfaction. All I got was the horrible ending and that vampire looked so stupid. Where's his teeth at? What does he bite people with? What vampire movie doesn't show the vampire's teeth. So
Strange very odd, very disappointing. Dracula , nineteen seventy nine was better than this

author: @timvoridis1120
text: I have just finished watching 'Nosferatu' and I truly have to say that Nicholas Hoult and Emma Corrin are killing it - they are superb and they should have been nominated at least for a BAFTA or an Academy Award. The cinematography, costumes, music and direction are excellent. The first half is way better and more 'ethereal' in a gothic horror way than the 2nd half, which is kind of a mess with elements from 'The exorcist', too much drama and annoying scenes. Lilly Rose Depp is good but overacting in many scenes and Johnson is miscast and boring in his role. Skarsgard, Dafoe and Ineson are entertaining, but the whole film is uneven; nevertheless, the 4K blu ray version must be a knockout.

author: @Gamingawesomeness121
text:
Well I guess it‚Äôs time i watched it. though i am not a fan of the director. But Looks interesting indeed, i will edit this comment after watching the film.

Edit: well it‚Äôs a Robert Eggers movie‚Ä¶ not really scary,over use of music, long unnecessary shots of people looking at things or looking for things, overacting and over playing the drama and feelings any conversation or situation is trying to portray. But awesome imagery, great use of blood and horror when it is shown, great portrayal of people going mad or being mad when it isn‚Äôt overreacting and justified for the characters with the appropriate scenes and good dialogue despite the overselling the drama. It took me half the movie to start caring and being interested i the events and what would happen but when it dis i found myself enjoying watching them unfold. Overall not bad honestly, i liked it. though i played it on 1.25x speed lol his films are longer than they should be imo.
Cant say i can rewatch it (at least not at its intended pace) but definitely better than the light house and maybe more enjoyable than the witch for me probably because this one is treated more like a monster movie.
I‚Äôd give it a 7 out of 10.

author: @NinjaBee81
text: Just saw the film, a bit late I might add. I have been a horror fan for a long time, and I kind of got scared of watching this because I saw so much backlash online towards it. "Boring, not good compared to the 90s Dracula etc." Well, I can truly say this was a spectacular film, truly a gothic masterpiece with excellent writing, directing, cinematography and acting. So if you are in doubt whether to watch it or not, please do. Also,  never have I seen an actor disappear to a role like Bill Skarsg√•rd did, you really can't tell it's him in anyway. The movie is fantastic and it's going to be a cult classic!

author: @aurelnicolaeion3764
text:
So manny things unexplained, let me break one for you guys ! You remember jn the beginning of the movie when those gipsy guys stick theirs object in the heart of the dead??! Those are called ‚ÄúStrigoi‚Äù in romanian culture or in english Strygwyr and there is no joke about them!
My mothet told me before like 100 years ago there weren‚Äôt manny people in the village like now, and sometimes when the decesead person died in a manner that not founded peace he would terrorised the family after death ! Like haunting them smashing plates all kinds of evil sounds and so on! My mother told me my grandfather used to gather with the community and if they suspected a dead beeing a ‚ÄúStrigoi‚Äù would open the grave ( wich is totally ilegal these days) and most of the times they would found the dead ( Strigoi) on a side üò≥ that meaning he left the grave during night to haunt the family. I know sounds stupid but these folk stories are real ! The they would take a long stick with a metal in the head and STAB THEM IN THE HEART ! In order to make sure they die , same like in the movie .
My mother comes from Craiova , wich is the region who created this mythical stories, and even now when I am 32 when she speaking about these shivers on my skin ! It is incredible

author: @darksoubarna
text:
This movie inspired such thoughts as mentioned below:

Dark visions of the distant past,
In thy vision a lover's farce
Create an image of imaginary treasure
To haunt a monster appears at last
Create the chaos, a lover leaves
Cloaked in darkness, chaos bleeds
Remarkable foe in black and white.
Creating moods of grey insight
The love it makes cries of longing
Winter comes but nothing it bodes
The monster creeps inside my bed
It crawls nibbles at my tits instead
It milks my horror and sadness fades
It creates images of happy warm days
As I suffocate and bleed on wedding bed
With the monster deep inside my head
Clear is my vision not fogged by death
I have clarity of my suffering in his stead
Soon he lingers in my soft flesh
A hard long finger under my bed
Clear again clairvoyance I gain
Deadly vision of death once again
Longing to see what happiness is
I cling to thee with my closed fists
Often a memory often my truth
He lies in my bed often misunderstood
There is no meaning to life if I am not dead
To die or live in him I shall rest
Atone for the sins I did not make
I shall lay in his unholy warm embrace

author: @JustHaroon56
text:
As a huge fan of the original Nosferatu films, especially the 1922 classic, I was really excited for Robert Eggers' new adaptation. But honestly, I was left pretty disappointed.

The visuals were undeniably stunning, and Eggers‚Äô attention to detail was great, but it didn‚Äôt hold a candle to the eerie, timeless atmosphere of the older films, especially the 1922 version. That movie still stands as one of the scariest and most atmospheric horror films of all time, and this new version just doesn‚Äôt compare. With all the talent in the cast‚ÄîWillem Dafoe, Bill Skarsg√•rd‚Äîit‚Äôs a shame they couldn‚Äôt have made a more gripping experience.

Lily-Rose Depp as Ellen didn‚Äôt work for me either. Her performance felt flat and didn‚Äôt carry the emotional weight the role needs. It‚Äôs like they had all the right pieces but still couldn‚Äôt capture what made the originals so unforgettable. For a 2025 film, I honestly expected something way more impactful. It‚Äôs visually beautiful, but as a whole, it missed the mark. I really think they could‚Äôve done better with all the advancements in filmmaking today.

author: @Darth_Sottoth
text:
It's really great that they kept the dark and fatalistic vibe of the book. Also, you can really feel the atmosphere of the Romantic era everywhere, with all its distinctive features. You've got the tormented hero and the girl ‚Äì of course, she's got tuberculosis, sleepwalking, and dark circles under her eyes. The intimate interiors and the overall gloomy atmosphere. Caspar David Friedrich seems to be all over the frames, plus there's this interest in mysticism and legends typical for that period.

If you‚Äôre familiar with the book and have some knowledge of art history and literature, it becomes even more interesting. But if you don‚Äôt know much, it might just come off as a "horror with jump scares for girls," like some people mentioned in other posts.

Of course, Count Orlok's character is very infernal, and the acting is incredible. Definitely watch it on the big screen during a late-night show.

author: @dshom
text: If you‚Äôre going to see this you need to set your expectations aside. This isn‚Äôt a jump-scare slasher movie. This is psychological horror set in a historical setting of 1800s Germany. The way they talk and dress is old school and like opening a time capsule. The movie is a remake of a silent film from the 1920s. If you understand and appreciate that you can enjoy this incredible film for what it is.

author: @CallmetheStorm
text:
Out of the theater for the 3rd time, and I gotta say, this is a really good film in general. I wouldn't say one of the greatest horror films of all time, but certainly within this decade for sure. The performances were great all around. They felt a little too much like performances from a stage play than of film, but I'm pretty sure that was intentional, because the performances in the original were stage play actors.

I might be in the minority here and I know the bad history of horror films with sequels, but I actually really want to see a sequel. A sequel that's from Tom's perspective, and him dealing with the aftermath. How is he holding up? How are the town holding up? How much did Ellen's sacrifice effect Tom? I would love for a sequel to answer to those questions. It would be realistic and heartbreaking to have the sequel showcase Tom as an overweight, pipe smoking and alcoholic drunk, trying to hide and suppress his shame, his rage and sadness. The plot could be to showcase Tom's growing obsession to call to Ellen, and how his actions will effect him and the town throughout the film

author: @NeilHynes
text: Was let down by this. It had jump scares, a disconnected story and raised little interest in the characters arcs. One of the main characters was constantly out of breath, scared and pretty much useless to anyone. I was waiting for a lead here. I didn't feel there was one. I'm really worried about movies like this that get loads of praise because of what I've outlined. I just couldn't connect with this movie. Compare this to Werner Herzogs 70's effort, or Francis Ford Coppola's 90's Dracula. Those movies do a better job of connecting with something in you, I feel.

author: @jollyrottenclown
text: As a gal that likes silent movies, and has a Max Schreck ‚ÄòNosferatu‚Äô tattoo slapped on her upper arm, I approve. I‚Äôm an absolute fan of all the films, and the original one still stands the test of time. When I first heard Robert Eggers was directing the film, I died, it was the perfect marriage, a match made in Hell. ‚ÄòThe Witch‚Äô ‚ÄòThe Lighthouse‚Äô were both exceptional dark and gritty atmospheric masterpieces, this movie did not disappoint, and the cast were all well chosen. And it was great to see Willem Dafoe back in it, playing the part of a backseat hero letting Skarsgard take the wheel as Orlok, representing my favorite all time vampire. There‚Äôs been some real lemons this year with films for me, so seeing Nosferatu exceed my wildest expectations, chefs kiss. Thank you Hollywood for letting Eggers get his hands on this slice of German and now American, cinema history. I cannot 5 star this film enough, go see it!

author: @wtfu812omg
text: Saw it today in imax. No not just to have my balls rumbled for 2 hours‚Ä¶‚Ä¶or maybe üòõ. Anyway it was fantastic.lil dramatic wit the acting and Willem Defoe always over the top. I was honestly worried about the fact that Count Orlock had a Stacie but honestly, it made sense considering he was Carpathian nobleman from back in the dark ages, so it wasn‚Äôt terrible, and honestly, the rest of them looked phenomenal from the rotting back of his head to his bony hands with elongated fingernails and a subtle but great detail was his nose which was large like somebody from that region but that there was decomposition  that showed where the skulls nasal passage starts but still covered with skin. And his skin was very corpse like without being night of the living dead. It was to show that he was continuing to feed on people to sustain his body as best he could from totally decomposition Ing and becoming what we‚Äôve known in movie law and video games as a Nosferatu vampire which are completely blue and spindly and pointy ears, etc. really something that is emaciated from lack of feeding. The fact that he had to hear and not very much because on the top of his head was next to nothing but enough that he could pull to the side, as if he still had some semblance of a man who was losing his hair, but tried to do a comb over, but then he died and became a vampire so he was stuck with what he had. The back of his head was awesome because it‚Äôs like he had been laying in his tomb every night on his dead skull and skin so not much was happening to retain it because of all the pressure and laying on his Back every night in his infernal tomb, and of course, by the middle of the movie you saw quite the reveal from his crypt yet it wasn‚Äôt the typical Nosferatu or Bram Stoker is Dracula, where he rises out of the tomb like he‚Äôs on an ironing board in a spring, which brings them up. This was so much more which I thought was cool because they didn‚Äôt use a whole lot of what they‚Äôve already seen in the past movies and of course you unfortunately got a full view of him because apparently he doesn‚Äôt wear clothes when he goes to bed, so it was pretty horrendous, and of course, by the end of the movie, you get a full back shot reveal of what he looks like, and it‚Äôs not pretty, but it really abuses the fact that he has a living dead being trying to sustain himself on feeding on blood and oh my God if you see the scenes where he is feeding all I can say is if you watch it in iMac, you‚Äôre really gonna hear it and feel it. That‚Äôs all I can say I don‚Äôt wanna ruin too much but all in all, this was a great movie. I highly recommend it. Yes, it is a bit artsy at times, but it‚Äôs also beautiful because much like in vein of the lighthouse in the witch. The attention to the detail of the backgrounds in settings are incredibly beautiful. And if I can also recommend another movie prior to going in to see this one was something that was just released and it‚Äôs on YouTube. It is a shot for shot remake of the 1922 Nosferatu movie but in color to a point and with acting and voice and sound starring the one and only Doug Jones, we know from Hellboy and other amazing roles where he has dressed up in full cost him much like Pam‚Äôs labyrinth. I literally just watched that one last night because I knew I was going to see Nosferatu 2024 tonight now they‚Äôre talking Oscars and that this movie will win one well I probably say yeah I don‚Äôt pay attention to that crap too much but this was definitely quite a movie for me having not been to the movie, theaters and years since the first avengers infinity war and I just stopped going to the movies for a very long time not so much due to Covid but just cause there was a lot of shit coming out, but I think this would highly recommend for one to go back to the theatres. üëçüëçüëçüëçüëç

author: @JJONNYREPP
text: NOSFERATU - Official Trailer [HD] - Only In Theaters December 25   0050am  4.1.25     just got home from seeing the movie, myself. very very interesting. and definitely worthy of  another viewing. roll on the dvd release!! the constant gloaming and dank scenery was a tad tiresome... though, i surmise, that was due to our being party to the world of count orloc. i dont think the film needed anyone providing a running commentary- if i get it then anyone can comprehend... basically, the film consisted of nods to various reiterations of the tale - from the original to the herzog presentation to gary oldman's histrionic laden count... i'd recommend this movie... and, let's face it, the monster gradually being made apparent in the literal cold light of day, to only die an inglorious death, wasn't too difficult a concept to grasp. the only problem is the picture seemed very much akin to a mish mash of skits spliced together - and defoe didn't seem to know who he was acting with.... and the overindulgence with the old CGI seemed to lessen and presence the actors/actresses may have had to project..................................... did sam raimi direct this?  to say i was sat in the cinema VIP lounge, those chairs aint half uncomfortable...

author: @rgbnights
text: Nosferatu? We walked out of AMC. It used every used horror movie scenario, like a quiet intro dialog suddenly shocked by a loud blast with a monster face. The timeline included waking up to a weird dream with muddy shoes, a cadaver humping an office worker, a pigeon getting its head bit off, the planks on this hundred-year-old ship being stained with deck waterproofing, a woman with exorcist contortions and screams, set up scenes with a lot of rats, lots of puke, and eating blood and guts, the creepy crypt and fake nail makeup was too clean, the voice of the monster was too fake and much too loud (like Darth Vader). And poor Willem Dafo ! He had to act with its amateur costuming and screenplay. The original 1922 silent German Expressionist vampire film directed by F. W. Murnau from a screenplay by Henrik Galeen was much creepier. Nosferatu 2024 is truly a horror of a movie, I couldn't wait to get out of there! The kids will love it.

text:
I noticed the vampire in the movie says humankind instead of mankind.

This is incorrect to the era the movie takes place in.

Humankind or people kind is the Woke terminology of mankind.

People who do not say mankind think they are being inclusive by saying human or people kind. They fail to realize that mankind includes both male and female. Just because a word has man as part of the word does not mean it‚Äôs about men. As an example the word women has men in the word yet the word refers to women.

In the era the movie takes place in they would have said mankind.

author: @GamXxEx
text:
Definitely worse than Coppola's 1992 film. Orlok was given a mustache, but this is supposed to be a remake of Murnau's version, where the vampire looked like a rat. Furthermore, the connection between Orlok and Ellen is unclear. Did she summon him as some kind of spirit? Why does he drink blood from her chest instead of her neck? Too little attention was given to the important parts of the original silent film, like Hutter finding the book about vampires or Orlok carrying coffins on a cart himself.

On the bright side, the acting, cinematography, sound, and gothic style are well-executed.
6.5/10.

author: @cjphx86
text: I was on Icon for the two weeks following the incident. We had 6600 passengers on the first week, and 6700 the second. I think this has to do with crowd size and diversity of the passengers. I felt irritable at the crowd size at Windjammer, but governed my frustration. I also wasn‚Äôt drinking. When you mix this many people, add irritation elements such as swollen crowds to just have a meal, and enhance frustration with alcohol, it can be a recipe for disaster. We had every race aboard and had no incidents, but I can understand how tempers may boil over. If you have a short temper, you probably shouldn‚Äôt go on the largest ship in the world with the most number of people.

author: @Valeriejeansolanas1
text:
The film not only disappointed me but also made me downright angry. It‚Äôs a prime example of how topics like sexuality are staged, ultimately serving only the male gaze. The female lead is relentlessly sexualized, while the film claims to be about the liberation of female sexuality and forbidden desires. This pseudo-feminist premise is infuriating. If that‚Äôs the case, the director shouldn‚Äôt try to sell it as anything else.

What I saw was nothing more than a drawn-out, aestheticized depiction of sexual violence‚Äîand that‚Äôs supposed to be feminist?

What I found especially problematic was how the relationship between the protagonist and the monster was portrayed. The woman is repeatedly assaulted by this creature, yet the film frames it as an expression of her hidden, taboo desires. Even if she might have initially consented to the relationship, that doesn‚Äôt make the repeated acts of violence any less what they are. Rather than critically examining such dynamics, the film glorifies them and markets them as groundbreaking.

What bothers me even more is that many critics have celebrated this film as "feminist." It feels like the audience is being taken for fools. Who genuinely believes that such a portrayal has anything to do with female empowerment or self-determination? The cinematography alone is telling: time and again, the female lead is captured in explicit, voyeuristic shots that are clearly designed to cater to male fantasies. Scenes where she‚Äôs filmed from above, approaching a man in a sexual manner, make it abundantly clear that this is not about a female perspective or liberation but about indulging a male voyeuristic gaze.

The nature shots and atmosphere in some scenes do deserve credit, but they cannot redeem the tasteless and objectionable overall depiction. Instead of breaking taboos or addressing feminist themes, the film perpetuates toxic stereotypes and cynically exploits the topic of female sexuality. All this left me feeling nothing but disappointment and the sense that my time had been wasted.

Oh, and besides all the serious criticism, the film was also boring and ridiculously dragged out üòÇ. Last time I felt this bored was in school. I‚Äôd almost forgotten what boredom feels like.

text: HUGE disappointment. First off, I absolutely hated the way Orlock looked. Looked NOTHING like the original Orlock which was the entire appeal. He could e at least bared some sort of resemblance instead having him sport a giant 70s porn mustache and male pattern baldness. Stupid. Skarsgard was great and his voice sounded ominous but he just looked ridiculous which ruined the whole thing. If the monster of the film doesnt frighten anyone then whats the point. Also I hate the fact that they kept NONE of the original iconic scenes from the original. Orlock didnt prowl around the ship, didnt rise up from his coffin, and didnt creep like he shouldve. Its a shame that a silent film from the 1920s was way creepier and than something made today.

author: @jerryschramm4399
text: This looks like a very good adaption of the original Bram Stoker novel. However, having it open on Christmas Day seems to be a miscalculation. How many people are going to want to see an art house production of a horror movie during the holiday season? This could very well doom it at the box office. I hope not, because, with the exception of "The Witch" (did anyone, anywhere understand what the father was saying in that film?), Eggars has made some terrific movies. I hope I'm wrong, and it tops the box office for a few weeks, and allows him to create more of these moody, twisted tales.

author: @The_Real_Danger_Mouse
text: More than 9 remakes so far that fail to capture the horror of the original.  The draw of the original was the feeling of being trapped in a decaying city infested by the plague at all corners.  Ellen is trapped in an apartment with only two ways out, through the rat-infested corridors or jumping out the window. With few options to save the city, she confronts the vampire.  The characters in this trailer look too wealthy.  They have a plethora of resources to confront the vampire including a body of guards and armament. The 1922 Count Orlok preyed upon vulnerable, easy targets that would not draw too much attention.  Ellen was the wife of an estate agent. If he was an assistant, he would make 20% more than a common laborer.  If he authored contracts and dealt with multiple accounts and hired a handful of agents, he could make up to 3 times the common laborer's wage. In the original, he does not employ anyone and would have been an assistant to an agent. The range of salaries in 2023 US levels would be $46,000 to $127,000 per year. Source: Register of Offices Jan 1, 1895, Washington Printing Office.  (The original movie was set in 1897).

author: @Yews
text:
The letters around the heptagram read ‚ÄòZalmoxis‚Äô.
Zalmoxis was the chief god of the Dacians (read: Romanians 2000 years ago), whose cult notably involved human sacrifice via impalement.
Also the version of the heptagram on Focus Features‚Äô official site (on Nosferatu-themed hoodies and whatnot) incorporates two dragons as ouroboroi (dragons swallowing each other‚Äôs tails), the dragons look like the Dacian dragon from the Classical era.
Looks like Eggers is trying to make Count Orlok Dacian or something, and perhaps connect »öepe»ô‚Äô reputation to the Classical Dacian cult. An issue with this is that Bram Stoker implies heavily his Dracula to be Hunnish (possibly Attila himself masquerading as a medieval Wallachian nobleman) rather than Dacian, and Count Orlok is not Dracula.
Anyway we shall see what the plot of the film could have to do with Zalmoxis.

I feel like this story is about dark temptation. Especially that one line she says ‚Äústanding before me was death, and yet I had never been more happy‚Äù
It‚Äôs about knowing your desires are wrong and cursed but not being able to fight them
Edit: when I wrote this comment I was unfamiliar with Gothic Horror and it‚Äôs themes. Since then I‚Äôve watched Nosferatu and looked more into the history. I now know that my comment wasn‚Äôt a huge revelation haha, it was just me subconsciously learning about gothic literature! I love it!

author: @tommyo.3535
text: Recently watched Werner Herzog's Nosferatu the Vampyre. It did everything it set out to do and achieves this transcendent naturalistic quality that feels special, and yet it all still felt distant and maybe even tame. It probably is a masterpiece in a way that I can't quite meet halfway. But I know Robert Eggers can take this story farther into more treacherous territory. This trailer tells me that nobody is innocent, that maybe they aren't worth saving. Maybe the worst thing is to fall short of total annihilation, and that maybe Nosferatu was right for bringing on the plague. I think Eggers will force us to sit with these troubling thoughts, and to face all the ugly confessions of these people, before Nosferatu begins his death journey. I know it's not fair to get ahead of myself with how it might be executed but I trust in Eggers to take it where it needs to go.

author: @markregehr4413
text: I've got high hopes for this film. I'll never forget seeing clips of the original Nosferatu as a kid and being scared of that spindly figure at night. I always thought I would see his shadow creeping up the stairs to slip into my room. Max Schreck is one of the greatest casting decisions of all time, and I don't think Klaus Kinski and Willem Defoe were able to capture his otherworldly, preternatural stare coupled with his rat-like teeth and spidery way of moving. There was a horror to the whole package deal of that man. I personally don't think Bill Skarsgard has the face and the look for this character either. His features are a bit too effete and feminine for the job (this was the case with Kinski as well, who had a droopy sadness to his eyes that kind of clouded out the dead-stare malice of the original). So we'll see. Even if Eggers took a wrong turn with his selection for Graf Orlock, I have no doubt that this film will be a masterpiece in its own right. Eggers has never let me down.

author: @BlobZombie
text:
The 1922 version directed by Murnau was a masterpiece and still my personal favorite vampire film.

The 1979 version directed by Werner Herzog was also just as incredible, as both English and German versions were filmed. If you haven't watched any of these, I highly recommend them. All of them.

May the third time with Robert Eggers be an equally pleasantly grotesque charm.

As a bonus, there's also Shadow of the Vampire that focuses on the making of the 1922 version, with Willem Dafoe portraying Max Shreck/ Count Orlok.

The only version I've yet to see is the 2023 version with Doug Jones's portrayal. I've met the man, so I'll do him the honor and check it out.

author: @vonbroz
text: As with any other remake of a film or work this old, there is something lost when transitioning from the original form (in this case, German Expressionism, into Hollywood) into something new. That's what I find spectacular about older films, they had much more primitive film technology, yet their work turns out more interesting than the modern day counterpart. Either way, I hope this film is good!

author: @danvol3835
text:
Everyone's byotchin' about why it wasn't a Hallowe'en release, but Xmas makes much more sense: Everyone's got multiple days off (for repeat viewings); visiting relatives who you'd rather go see a movie with (so you don't have to talk to them for a couple of hours); you don't have to deal with snotty little kids who you have to take out trick-or-treating.
Personally, Hallowe'en is for teeny-boppers--let 'em see some slasher or gore-fest. Meanwhile, the adults can unwind on a holiday-season afternoon or evening with some juicy, atmospheric cinema.

author: @miacgcvampiros
text:
As far as I know this movie is an important summary of all Nosferatu (1922, 1931, 1979...): the "suspense" remember me the obscure atmosphere for Orlok, or desolated streets with coffins for Kinski.
About the "donna", she show me an intensive "contralto" between Greta Schr√∂der and Isabelle Adjani but her sadness have knowedge (in philosophic terms).
In relations with the great Dafoe his interpretation of Van Helsign is supreme just because the actoral manifestation is hateful (an special love/hate about your work for me always!).
I waiting for this New Nosferatu! It could be blessed by Marnau and Herzog!

author: @Frantic857
text:
The first time that Jesus came, He came as the sacrificial Lamb of God.
+
(Matthew 5:17 > Think not that I came to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy but to fulfill.)
+
Jesus dying on the cross as the ultimate and eternal sacrifice, who shed His blood for the whole world.
+
(Hebrews 9:22 > And almost all things are by the law purged with blood; and without shedding of blood is no remission.)
+
Old Testament law required the sacrifice of an animal to cover sins, preferably a spotless lamb in order to have your sins covered. This was a continual and ongoing process.
+
Jesus was the last and only sacrifice that actually forgave a persons sins, past, present, and future!
+
(Romans 10:9-10 > [9]-That id thou shalt confess with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved.
[10]-For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.)
+
(Romans 10:13 > For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.)
+
Right now is the "church age" or age of grace!
+
(Ephesians 2:8-9 > [8]-For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not oof yourselves: it is a gift of God:
[9]-Not of works, lest any man should boast.)
+
When you give yourself to the Lord, you are given the Holy Spirit / the Comforter. It indwells you and seals you until the day of redemption when the Lord returns for His bride, which is the Church, those who believe and invite the Lord into their lives.
+
And if you do not do this, then the Lord is coming back as the Lion of the Tribe of Judah. Who will be coming to pass judgement on a fallen world.
+
This time period known to the lost world as, Armageddon or the Great Tribulation will actually destroy over two thirds of the worlds population.
+
But if you are a saved / born again believer, (John 3:3-5) you will be raptured out by the Lord before this world judgement starts.
+
I hope and pray that you are saved in Jesus' name. Amen!

author: @yj7jjjuk5fghira
text:
Councilwoman: No One Should Have Their Organs Harvested Alive
After watching the documentary, Taichung City Councilor Chen Ya-Hui said that her father accompanied a friend years ago to China to have an organ transplant surgery. They were told that the organ came from a death-row prisoner. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs quite a shock,‚Äù she said after knowing that the organ came from an innocent living person. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs impossible to have that many people die and donate their organs every day. The number of transplants was unfathomable.‚Äù


Taichung City Councilor Chen Ya-Hui said that no one should have their organs harvested against their will.

Ms. Chen said she often saw Falun Dafa practitioners meditating in the park when she went there for morning exercises. She believed that no one should have their organs taken against his will, especially for such a big peaceful group being the main target in the crime. ‚ÄúWe are all human beings and we should not take organs from others just because we want to live,‚Äù she stressed that everyone should receive organs from legal donations, not killing.

She continued to say that live organ harvesting was cruel. In Taiwan, if someone disappears, the authorities would try their best to find him or her. It‚Äôs absolutely not permitted for someone to be killed for their organs in Taiwan. She would jointly sign the motion against organ harvesting in the City Council.

author: @STho205
text:
Nosferatu was made a couple of years after the great pandemic, and had overtones of a plague of creeping evil coming with the vampire...not just the biting of victims like the Universal film of the 30s. Once defeated the miasma of death subsided as well.

From the trailer it looks like the centennial remake is capturing the similar real life time and same ambience.

author: @chaosfive55
text: I verily believe that this is going to make cinematic history.  How could it not?  NOSFERATU is the result of a creative alliance spanning two centuries: Bram Stoker gave us Dracula in 1897--Murnau gave us Nosferatu in 1922---Werner Herzog breathed new unlife into it in 1979...and now Eggers puts the icing on the stake.

author: @sassyimps
text:
I'm so happy this is finally being made. But I have a couple criticisms:
- There needs to be a black-and-white version; silent would be an awesome bonus
- I dislike the "larger than life" portrayal of Orlok here, it removes probably the scariest thing about him from the original: his humanity. His normalcy made his lack of it so much more disturbing. Here, dude's literally an eldritch, demonic entity, which is cool, don't get me wrong. But it lacks tangibility.

Either way, Dafoe is going to kill this performance, I know it.

Nonetheless the trailer looks very promising, if im sincere i give it a 8/10 ill definetly watch it when it comes out and im curious after watching the scenes which is weird in this era of internet.

text:
One gripe about this, and especially towards Eggers and his accuracy and respect to the era, but I don‚Äôt like when a period piece only uses English accents, especially from non-English actors. His last film, The Northman, wasn‚Äôt Norse aside a few actors, but he had them speak thusly. Here, and especially towards his favorite film of all time, I‚Äôm surprised they‚Äôre not going for German accents.

author: @redadamearth
text: Honestly, I'm kind of surprised by the fact that visually and tonally, this doesn't look much different than Coppola's "Dracula", albeit with better acting for Harker. I would have thought Eggers would have added more visionary elements to the story. It just looks like a very....traditional telling of Stoker's story with some extremely rote horror visuals. The little girls, the curtain, the shadows, it just all looks rather "done" to me. Hoping that the trailer is a red herring and that there's something new, here. Don't get me wrong, I'm always down for a well-told version of the story, just hoping there's something new brought to it.

author: @KenjiIsidor
text:
Nicholas Hoult : "Another movie where I have to fight against Dracula. Wait ? He's not played by Nicolas Cage and his name is Count Orlock ? What ?"
Willem Dafoe : "Yeah because the original movie was an adaptation from Bram Stoker's original book made without his authorisation so they made some changes..."
Nicholas : "Hold up. You seems to really know your subject..."
Willem Dafoe : "Yeah, I'm the guy who play this version of Dracula in the movie Shadow of the vampire."
Nicholas : "Oh so you were Count Orlock ?"
Willem Dafoe : "No no no I played the guy who played him in the original movie. His name was Max Schreck and some people thought he was a true vampire !"
Christopher Walken : "I played Max Schreck too."
Willem Dafoe : "Oh really ?"
Christopher : "And I fought Batman and Catwoman."
Nicholas :" I am so confuse right now."

author: @gman-29
text: Please not another version where the Mina character is actually the reincarnation of Dracula's wife and their love is destined to cross centuries, and they are actually the good guys and those who hunt Dracula are actually the bad guys because they just don't understand his tortured soul.  But Mina does.  Dracula may be jerk but she believes she is the one special girl who has access to his true tenderness and truly understands him and so remains addicted to her abusive relationship with him.  Knowing how modern films go, this will likely be a symbolic movie of Dracula giving Mina the power to rise above the evil society that holds back her greatness.  Nevermind all they people he kills... the movie will justify it as they were part of that evil society and thus worthy of destruction.

author: @battousai9795
text: I'm not saying that this is going to be bad, because it looks great, it's just that this feels way too... movie-like? The thing about the original and the 79 remake was that they weren't super big budget films, and that gave them a feeling of being something that might have actually happened, even when it obviously didn't and wouldn't even be possible. This comes across as less genuine for some reason. It's very clearly a Hollywood production with movie sets, costume design, big name authors, and very intentional cinematography. It doesn't feel like I'm gonna go see the Nosferatu story, it feels like I'm gonna go watch Robert Egger's work. It doesn't have that visceral feeling that the other two had.

author: @actnowwithsteviedow
text: Only in theaters‚Ä¶on Christmas Day. Christmas Day? Do you know how many people are going to go and see this on Christmas Day? Literally zero. The holiday release date worked for Scream, but that was a fluke decades ago, and it wasn‚Äôt on bloody Christmas Day. That‚Äôs really taking this piss. What is this aversion to releasing horror movies in October? Do you know how many people would go and see this in October? I would. All my friends would. I will not however be going out to see this on Christmas Day and will most likely wait till it‚Äôs out on streaming. Again, had it been October you‚Äôd have got my money. If you insist on it being a Christmas movie, at least release it before Christmas Day. Do you know when everyone goes to the theater at Christmas? On Christmas Eve. You know that, right?

author: @jonasulrich
text: I'm not sold by the casting... when did Eggers go that mainstream? I think the casting in THE VVITCH was phenomenal precisely because it wasn't well-known faces, which really helped you to get into the period setting. And even if Dafoe and Pattinson are well-known, their casting in THE LIGHTHOUSE was inspired and surprising. But this? Sure, Dafoe looks good. But Lily-Rose Depp? That's the best young actress you could find? Might as well have cast Lily Collins. And Nicholas Hoult? Dude just starred in a Dracula comedy LAST YEAR. An overused Hollywood face with zero edge to it. Fingers crossed for Orlok himself, but here as well... Bill Skarskard? The guy who gets cast as creepy bad guy in EVERY hollywood (horror) movie? OK.
